nodes.bodyText: I think it's more descriptive to name the method resolve(), with 'parent' and 'child' instead of 'left' and 'right'.

nodes.bodyText: by convention, anything that isn't annotated as @Nullable is assumed to be non-null, and in general we try to avoid null values when possible. When would be trying to merge a null?

nodes.bodyText: I don't think we should allow seqId to be null, as that isn't a valid representation of stored preferences. It forces the caller of getSeqId() to handle a null, which shouldn't ever be the case
Done

Actually seqId could be null when preferences never get set on the entity. Given the fact that seqId > 0, I am using 0 as default value when preferences are not present. This is consistent with current contact that property map is empty when preferences are not set.

I see. Does this cause any issues if preferences are set and then deleted? If the sequence number gets reset in that scenario, it would mean some of the assumptions in that metadata processor are false.
Deletion just clear the map but still bump up the seqId. So the only case seqId is not there is the entity never had any preferences set on it.
I believe sendJson will serialize the object to json automatically, which mean you don't need the GSON.toJson()

void sendJson(HttpResponseStatus status, String jsonString);
Don't we still need GSON.toJson() to convert to jsonString?
oh this is the netty responder, got this mixed up with HttpServiceResponder. Ignore my comment.
Resolved.
this should be returning a 404 if the app exists but the program does not
this can be done with Store.ensureProgramExists()

if it can't be null, it should be a long instead of a Long
